Chapter 10, Part 5: The Bodhisattva King of Sublime Virtue of Universal Radiance
Furthermore, good sons!
How do bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas cultivate the subtle teachings of the MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a and fully accomplish the seventh merit?
Good sons!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas cultivate the subtle teachings of the MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a and contemplate thus:
'What dharmas can serve as proximate causes for the great parinirvÄá¹‡a?'
The bodhisattvas immediately know that there are four kinds of dharmas that serve as proximate causes for the great parinirvÄá¹‡a.
If it is said that diligently cultivating all austerities is a proximate cause for the great parinirvÄá¹‡a, this is not so.
Why is it so?
If one can attain parinirvÄá¹‡a apart from the four dharmas, there is no such possibility.
What are the four?
First, to be close to good friends, second, to listen to the Dharma single-mindedly, third, to contemplate with focused attention, and fourth, to practice in accordance with the Dharma.
Good man!

It is like a person who encounters various illnesses, whether hot or cold, exhaustion or malaria, or various demonic poisons, going to a good doctor, and the good doctor immediately prescribing medicine according to the illness.

This person sincerely accepts the doctor's instructions, prepares the medicine according to the instructions, and takes it as prescribed. After taking it, the illness is cured and the body attains peace and joy.

A sick person is likened to the bodhisattvas, a good doctor is likened to a good and virtuous friend, the prescriptions of a good doctor are likened to the Vaipulya sutras, sincerely accepting the doctor's instructions is likened to skillfully contemplating the meaning of the Vaipulya sutras, preparing the medicine according to the instructions is likened to practicing the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment in accordance with the Dharma, the cure of the illness is likened to the elimination of afflictions, and attaining peace and joy is likened to attaining nirvana, permanence, bliss, self, and purity.
Good man!
It is like a king who wishes to rule according to the Dharma, bringing peace and happiness to the people, consulting with wise ministers, asking, What is the method?
The ministers then explain the old laws of the former kings.

When the king has heard them, he faithfully practices them with utmost sincerity, ruling the country according to the Dharma, without any enemies. Therefore, he brings peace and happiness to the people, free from troubles.
Good man!

The king is a metaphor for the bodhisattvas, the wise ministers are a metaphor for the good and wise friends, the method of governance explained by the wise ministers is a metaphor for the twelve divisions of the scriptures, the king's hearing and faithfully practicing with utmost sincerity is a metaphor for the bodhisattvas contemplating the profound meanings in the twelve divisions of the scriptures with a focused mind, ruling the country according to the Dharma is a metaphor for the bodhisattvas practicing according to the Dharma, namely the six pÄramitÄs. Because they are able to cultivate the six pÄramitÄs, they have no enemies, a metaphor for the bodhisattvas already free from the bandits of the afflictions and evil thieves, attaining peace and happiness is a metaphor for the bodhisattvas attaining the great nirvÄá¹‡a of permanence, bliss, self, and purity.
Good sons!
It is like a person who encounters a severe leprosy. A good friend tells him:
'If you can go to the side of Mount Sumeru, your illness can be cured.
Why is this?
There is a good medicine there, tasting like nectar. If you can take it, the illness will be cured.
' The person, with a sincere mind, believing in this matter, then goes to the mountain, takes the nectar, and the illness is cured, and the body attains peace and joy.

The severe leprosy illness is a metaphor for ordinary beings, the good friend is a metaphor for the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, the sincere belief and acceptance is a metaphor for the four immeasurables, Mount Sumeru is a metaphor for the eightfold noble path, the nectar taste is a metaphor for buddha-nature, the cure of the leprosy illness is a metaphor for being free from afflictions, and attaining peace and joy is a metaphor for attaining the nirvÄá¹‡a of permanence, bliss, self, and purity.
Good sons!
It is like a person who raises disciples who are intelligent and greatly wise. This person always teaches them day and night without becoming weary.
The bodhisattvas are also like this. All sentient beings may have faith or may lack faith, but they always teach and transform without weariness.
Good man!
Good and virtuous friends refer to bodhisattvas, buddhas, pratyekabuddhas, Å›rÄvakas, and those among people who have faith in the MahÄyÄna.
Why are they called good and virtuous friends?

Good and virtuous friends are able to teach sentient beings to stay far away from the ten evil deeds and to cultivate the ten wholesome deeds. For this reason, they are called good and virtuous friends.
Furthermore, good and virtuous friends speak in accordance with the Dharma and practice in accordance with their speech.
What is meant by speaking in accordance with the Dharma and practicing in accordance with one's speech?

Not killing oneself, and teaching others not to kill, up to practicing right view oneself and teaching others right view. If one is able to do this, then one can be called a true good and virtuous friend.
Cultivating enlightenment oneself, and also being able to teach others to cultivate enlightenment. For this reason, they are called good and virtuous friends.

One is able to cultivate oneself in faith, precepts, giving, learning, and wisdom, and is also able to teach others faith, precepts, giving, learning, and wisdom. For this reason, they are called good and virtuous friends.
Good and virtuous friends possess wholesome qualities.
What are the wholesome qualities?

They do not seek their own happiness in their actions, but always seek happiness for sentient beings. Seeing others' faults, they do not expose their shortcomings. Their mouths always proclaim purely wholesome matters. For this reason, they are called good and virtuous friends.
Good son!
Just as the moon in the sky gradually grows from the first to the fifteenth day,
good and virtuous friends are also like this, causing learners to gradually distance themselves from unwholesome qualities and increase wholesome qualities.
Good son!

If one draws near to a good and wise advisor, one who has not yet attained morality, concentration, wisdom, liberation, and the knowledge and insight of liberation will come to have them, and one who has not yet perfected them will be able to increase them.
Why is this?
It is because of drawing near to a good and wise advisor. Because of this intimacy, one will also be able to comprehend the profound meaning of the twelve divisions of the scriptures.

If one is able to listen to the profound meaning of the twelve divisions of the scriptures, it is called listening to the Dharma. Listening to the Dharma refers to the Mahayana Vaipulya scriptures. Listening to the Vaipulya sutras is called truly listening to the Dharma. Truly listening to the Dharma means listening to and accepting the MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra. In the MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a, one hears of the Buddha-nature and that the TathÄgata ultimately does not enter parinirvÄá¹‡a. Therefore, it is called listening to the Dharma with a focused mind. Listening to the Dharma with a focused mind is the Eightfold Noble Path. Because the Eightfold Noble Path is able to eliminate greed, anger, and delusion, it is called listening to the Dharma.
Those who listen to the Dharma are called the eleven kinds of emptiness, using these emptinesses to not form appearances of any dharmas.
Those who listen to the Dharma are called those who first give rise to the mind, up to the mind of unsurpassed, perfect, complete awakening.
Because of the initial mind, one attains great nirvÄá¹‡a, not because of hearing one attains great nirvÄá¹‡a, but because of cultivation one attains great nirvÄá¹‡a.
Good man!
It is like a sick person who, although they hear the doctor's instructions and the names of the medicines, cannot be cured by just that, but can be cured by taking the medicine.

Although one listens to the twelve profound principles of dependent arising, one cannot eliminate all afflictions, one must be mindful and contemplate well in order to be able to eliminate them. This is called the third, being mindful and contemplating.
What is the meaning of being mindful and contemplating?
It refers to the three samÄdhis:
The samÄdhi of emptiness, the samÄdhi of signlessness, and the samÄdhi of wishlessness.

Emptiness means not seeing any reality in the twenty-five [existences]. No-doer means not making any wishes or requests regarding the twenty-five [existences]. No-mark means being free from the ten marks, namely, the marks of form, sound, smell, taste, touch, birth, abiding, cessation, male, and female. Cultivating such three concentrations is called the bodhisattva's focused contemplation.
What is called practicing in accordance with the Dharma?

Practicing in accordance with the Dharma is precisely practicing the perfection of giving and so forth up to the perfection of wisdom. Knowing the true characteristics of the aggregates, sense bases, and elements is also the same as the Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and buddhas, who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a through the same one path.
The Dharma is precisely permanence, bliss, self, and purity; non-birth, non-aging; non-sickness, non-death; not hungry, not thirsty; not suffering, not troubled; not regressing, not sinking.
Good man!
Those who understand the profound meaning of the great parinirvÄá¹‡a know that the buddhas will never finally enter nirvÄá¹‡a.
Good sons!
The foremost true good and virtuous friend is the bodhisattvas and the buddhas, the world-honored ones.
Why is it so?
Because they always skillfully tame with three things.
What are the three?
First, ultimately gentle speech; second, ultimately scolding; third, gentle speech and scolding.
For this reason, the bodhisattvas and buddhas are true good and virtuous friends.
Furthermore, good sons!
Because the buddhas and bodhisattvas are great physicians, they are called good and virtuous friends.
Why is it so?
Because they know the illness, know the medicine, and prescribe the medicine according to the illness.
It is like a good doctor who is skilled in the eight methods. First, he observes the signs of the illness.
There are three kinds of signs.
What are the three?
They are wind, heat, and water.
For those with wind illnesses, he gives them ghee and oil.
To those with a fever, he gives them rock candy.
To those with a water illness, he gives them ginger soup.
Because he knows the root of the illness and gives medicine to cure it, he is called a good doctor.
The Buddhas and Bodhisattvas are also like this. They know that ordinary beings have three kinds of illnesses:
First, desire, second, anger, and third, ignorance.

For those with the illness of desire, they teach them to contemplate the appearance of bones. For those with the illness of anger, they contemplate the appearance of kindness and compassion. For those with the illness of ignorance, they contemplate the appearance of the twelve links of dependent origination.
For this reason, the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas are called good and virtuous friends.
Good man!
Just as a great ship captain is called a great ship captain because he skillfully ferries people across,
the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas are also like this. They ferry sentient beings across the great ocean of birth and death.
For this reason, they are called good and virtuous friends.
Furthermore, good man!
Because of the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas, sentient beings are able to fully cultivate and attain the fundamental goodness.
Good man!
It is like the Himalayas, which are the source of various wonderful and superior medicines.
The Buddhas and Bodhisattvas are also like this, all being the source of all wholesome roots.
For this reason, they are called good and virtuous friends.
Good man!

In the Himalayas there is a superior fragrant medicine called sahe. If a person sees it, they will attain immeasurable longevity, free from illness and suffering. Even the four poisons cannot harm them. If one touches it, their lifespan will be extended to 120 years. If one thinks of it, they will attain the wisdom of past lives.
Why is this?
Because of the power of the medicine.

The Buddhas and Bodhisattvas are also like this. If one sees them, one will immediately be able to eliminate all afflictions. Even the four demons cannot disturb them. If one touches them, their life cannot be cut short, they will not be born, will not die, will not regress, and will not sink.
What is meant by touching them? If one is by the Buddha's side listening to and receiving the wonderful Dharma.
If one has mindfulness, one will attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.
For this reason, the buddhas and bodhisattvas are called good and virtuous friends.
Good man!
In the Fragrant Mountains, there is the Anavatapta Pond. Because of this pond, there are four great rivers, namely the Ganges, the Sindhu, the Vaksu, and the SÄ«tÄ.
Sentient beings in the world always say:
'If there are those with offenses, bathing in these four rivers can eliminate all offenses.'
One should know that these words are false and untrue. Apart from this, what is true?
The buddhas and bodhisattvas are true.
Why is this?
If a person draws near, they can eliminate all offenses.
For this reason, they are called good and virtuous friends.
Moreover, good man!

It is like the great earth, where all medicinal herbs, trees, forests, a hundred grains, sugarcane, flowers, and fruits, when struck by the hot weather and drought are about to wither and die, the dragons Nanda and Upananda, out of compassion for sentient beings, emerge from the great ocean and pour down sweet rain, causing all forests, a hundred grains, and plants to be nourished and grow again.

All sentient beings are also like this. The wholesome roots they possess are about to be exhausted. The Buddhas and Bodhisattvas give rise to great compassion and pour down the rain of sweet dew from the ocean of wisdom, causing sentient beings to fully regain the Dharma of the ten wholesome deeds.
For this reason, the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas are called good and virtuous friends.
Good man!

It is like a good doctor skilled in the eight branches of medicine, who, when seeing patients, does not consider their social class, whether they are handsome or ugly, or their wealth and possessions, but treats them all. For this reason, he is called a great good doctor in the world.

The buddhas and bodhisattvas are also like this. Seeing that sentient beings have the illness of afflictions, they do not consider their family lineage, whether they are upright or beautiful, or their money, property, or valuables. With a compassionate mind, they expound the Dharma for them all. When sentient beings hear it, their illnesses of afflictions are cured.
For this reason, the buddhas and bodhisattvas are called good and virtuous friends.
By relying on good and virtuous friends, one can then approach great parinirvÄá¹‡a.
How do bodhisattvas, by the causal conditions of listening to the Dharma, get close to great parinirvÄá¹‡a?

Because all sentient beings listen to the Dharma, they are endowed with the faculty of faith. Because they obtain the faculty of faith, they enjoy practicing giving, upholding precepts, being patient, making energetic progress, cultivating meditation, and developing wisdom. They attain the fruit of stream-entry up to the fruit of buddhahood. Therefore, you should know that attaining all wholesome dharmas is the power of the causal conditions of listening to the Dharma.
Good man!
It is like an elder who has only one son. He sends him to another country to trade for necessities. He shows him the roads, the passages, and the places of danger. He also warns him:
If you encounter a prostitute, do not be intimate with her. If you are intimate with her, you will lose your life, your body, and your wealth.
Do not associate with evil and wicked people.
The son respectfully obeyed his father's instructions, and his body and mind were at ease, and he obtained much treasure.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas expound the essentials of the Dharma for sentient beings in the same way. They show sentient beings and the four groups of Buddhist followers the passages and blockages of the paths. Because these sentient beings hear the Dharma, they distance themselves from evil and perfect wholesome dharmas.
For this reason, the causes and conditions of listening to the Dharma enable one to approach great parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Good man!
It is like a clear mirror that reflects a person's face, without any obscurity.
Listening to the Dharma is also like a bright mirror, if a person reflects on it, they will see good and evil clearly without obstruction.
For this reason, the causes and conditions of listening to the Dharma can lead to the great parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Good sons!

It is like a merchant who wants to reach a treasure island but does not know the road. Someone shows him the way, and the merchant follows the instructions to reach the treasure island and obtains countless precious treasures.

All sentient beings are also like this. They want to reach a good place and gather the treasures of the Way, but they do not know the passable and impassable roads. The bodhisattvas show them, and the sentient beings follow to reach the good place and obtain the treasure of the great nirvÄá¹‡a.
For this reason, the causes and conditions of listening to the Dharma can lead to the great parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Good sons!
It is like a drunken elephant, mad, foolish, violent, and wanting to kill.
There is an elephant trainer who uses a large iron hook to hook the top of the elephant's head, and it immediately becomes obedient, with all evil thoughts completely gone.

All sentient beings are also like this. Because of being intoxicated by greed, anger, and delusion, they wish to create much evil. Bodhisattvas use the hook of hearing the Dharma to hook them and make them stay, and they are no longer able to give rise to the mind of creating evil.
For this reason, the causes and conditions of listening to the Dharma can lead to the great parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Therefore, I have said in various sÅ«tras:

'If my disciples single-mindedly listen to and accept the twelve divisions of the scriptures, they will be free from the five hindrances and cultivate the seven factors of awakening. By cultivating the seven factors of awakening, they will be able to approach the great parinirvÄá¹‡a.'
Because of listening to the Dharma, those who have entered the stream are free from all fear.
Why is it so?

The elder Sudatta suffered from a serious illness and was greatly distressed. Hearing ÅšÄriputra speak of the four merits and ten kinds of consolation of a stream-enterer, upon hearing this his fear was immediately dispelled.

Why is it so?
Because it opens the eye of the Dharma.
There are three kinds of people in the world:
The first are those without eyes, the second have one eye, and the third have two eyes.

Those without eyes never hear the Dharma, those with one eye temporarily hear the Dharma but their minds do not dwell in it, and those with two eyes single-mindedly listen and accept it, and practice according to what they hear.
Because of listening to the Dharma, one knows that there are such three kinds of people in the world.

Just as in the past, when I was in the city of KuÅ›inagara, ÅšÄriputra was afflicted by illness. I then instructed the bhiká¹£u Ä€nanda to extensively expound the Dharma for him.
At that time, ÅšÄriputra, having heard of this matter, told his four disciples:

After hearing the Dharma, by the power of hearing the Dharma, his suffering was cured and his body became peaceful and at ease.
For this reason, the cause and condition of listening to the Dharma leads to being close to the great parinirvÄá¹‡a.
How does a bodhisattva attain being close to the great parinirvÄá¹‡a by means of contemplation and cause and condition?
Because of this contemplation, the mind attains liberation.

All sentient beings are always inverted by the four dharmas of permanence, bliss, self, and purity. By contemplating, they can see that all dharmas are impermanent, without bliss, without self, and without purity. Having seen this, the four inversions are then eliminated.
For this reason, contemplating causes and conditions can bring one close to the great parinirvÄá¹‡a.

All dharmas have four characteristics.
What are the four?
First, the characteristic of birth; second, the characteristic of aging; third, the characteristic of sickness; fourth, the characteristic of cessation.
These four characteristics can cause all ordinary sentient beings up to srotÄpannas to experience great suffering;
If one can focus the mind and contemplate well, then even encountering these four, one will not give rise to suffering.
For this reason, contemplating causes and conditions can bring one close to the great parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Moreover, good man!
All wholesome dharmas are not attained without contemplating.
Why is it so?

Although someone may listen to the Dharma with a focused mind for immeasurable, limitless, and incalculable eons, if they do not contemplate, they will ultimately be unable to attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.
For this reason, the cause and condition of contemplation can lead to the attainment of great parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Furthermore, good man!

If there are sentient beings who have faith in the Buddha, Dharma, and Saá¹ƒgha, without change, and give rise to reverence, you should know that this is all due to the power of the cause and condition of focused contemplation, and thus they are able to eliminate all afflictions.
For this reason, the cause and condition of contemplation can lead to the attainment of great parinirvÄá¹‡a.
How do bodhisattvas practice in accordance with the Dharma?
Good man!
Cutting off unwholesome dharmas and cultivating wholesome dharmas is called bodhisattvas' practice in accordance with the Dharma.
Furthermore, what is practicing in accordance with the Dharma?

Seeing all dharmas as empty and nonexistent, impermanent, without joy, without self, and impure, by seeing this, one would rather give up one's life than violate the precepts. This is called the bodhisattva's practice in accordance with the Dharma.
Next, what is practice in accordance with the Dharma?
Cultivation is of two kinds:
One is true, the other is not true.
The not true is not knowing the characteristics of nirvana, buddha-nature, tathagata, dharma, sangha, true suchness, emptiness, etc. This is called not true.
What is true?
Being able to know the characteristics of nirvana, buddha-nature, tathagata, dharma, sangha, true suchness, emptiness, etc. This is called true.
What is called knowing the characteristics of nirvana?
The characteristics of nirvana are generally eight things.
What are the eight?
One is exhaustion, two is good nature, three is reality, four is truth, five is permanence, six is joy, seven is self, and eight is purity. This is called nirvana.
There are also eight aspects.
What are the eight?
First, liberation; second, wholesome nature; third, unreality; fourth, untruth; fifth, impermanence; sixth, no bliss; seventh, no self; eighth, no purity.
There are also six characteristics:
First, liberation; second, wholesome nature; third, unreality; fourth, untruth; fifth, peace and bliss; sixth, purity.
If sentient beings rely on the worldly path to eliminate afflictions, such nirvÄá¹‡a has eight aspects of liberation that are unreal.
Why is this?
Because it is impermanent.

Because of impermanence, there is no reality. Because there is no reality, there is no truth. Although afflictions are eliminated, because they arise again, there is impermanence, no self, no bliss, and no purity. This is called the eight aspects of liberation in nirvÄá¹‡a.
What are the six characteristics?
Because the Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas have eliminated afflictions, they are called liberated, but they are not yet able to attain supreme perfect enlightenment, so they are called unreal.
Because they are unreal, they are called not true.
Because in the future they will attain supreme perfect enlightenment, they are called impermanent.
Because they have attained the eight uncontaminated holy paths, they are called pure and blissful.
Good man!
If one knows in this way, it is knowing nirvÄá¹‡a, but it is not called buddha-nature, tathÄgata, Dharma, saá¹ƒgha, true reality, or space.

The buddha-nature has six aspects.
What are the six?
One, permanent; two, pure; three, real; four, good; five, to be seen in the future; six, true.
There are also seven aspects:
One, can be realized; the other six are the same as above. This is called the bodhisattvas knowing the buddha-nature.
How do bodhisattvas know the characteristics of the TathÄgata?

The TathÄgata is the characteristic of enlightenment, the characteristic of goodness, permanence, bliss, self, purity, liberation, reality, the path that can be seen. This is called the bodhisattva's knowledge of the characteristics of the TathÄgata.

The Dharma refers to what is good and not good, permanent and impermanent, blissful and not blissful, self and no-self, pure and impure, known and unknown, understood and misunderstood, true and untrue, cultivated and not cultivated, a teacher and not a teacher, real and unreal. Because all Å›rÄvakas attain the Buddha's path.

Because they realize the nature of dharmas.

The true reality is neither permanent nor impermanent, neither blissful nor not blissful, neither self nor not self, neither pure nor impure, neither good nor not good, neither existent nor non-existent, neither nirvana nor not nirvana, neither liberation nor not liberation, neither knowing nor not knowing, neither cutting off nor not cutting off, neither realizing nor not realizing, neither cultivating nor not cultivating, neither seeing nor not seeing. Although the Buddha and Bodhisattvas have the five eyes, they do not see it.
Only the eye of wisdom can see it. What the eye of wisdom sees is no dharma that can be seen, and thus it is called seeing.

If what has no substance is called empty space, such empty space is called real. Because it is real, it is called permanent and non-existent. Because it is permanently non-existent, it has no joy, self, or purity.
Good man!
Emptiness is called the absence of dharmas. The absence of dharmas is called emptiness. It is like the world calling the absence of things empty.
The nature of empty space is also like this. Because it has nothing, it is called empty space.
Good man!
The nature of sentient beings and the nature of empty space both have no real nature.
Why is it so?
It is like a person saying, Remove existing things and then make space. But this empty space is actually uncreatable.
Why is it so?ğŸ”½Because it has nothing.
Because it has nothing, one should know there is no emptiness.
If this nature of space can be created, then it is impermanent. If it is impermanent, it cannot be called space.
Good man!
People in the world say that space is formless, unobstructed, and eternally unchanging, therefore the Dharma of space is called the fifth great element.
Good man!
But this space actually has no nature. Because of light, it is called space, but there is no real space.
It is just like the conventional truth, which actually has no nature, but is spoken of as having conventional truth for the sake of sentient beings.
Good man!

The essence of nirvana is also like this. There is no place of abiding. It is simply the place where the buddhas sever afflictions, therefore it is called nirvana. Nirvana is precisely permanence, bliss, self, and purity. Although nirvana is bliss, it is not the bliss of sensation. It is the supreme, wondrous bliss of cessation.
The buddhas and tathagatas have two kinds of bliss:
First, the bliss of cessation; second, the bliss of awareness.
The essence of reality has three kinds of bliss:
First, the bliss of sensation, second, the bliss of tranquility, and third, the bliss of awareness.
Buddha-nature is one bliss, because it is to be seen. When attaining supreme perfect enlightenment, it is called the bliss of enlightenment.
At that time, the Bodhisattva-MahÄsattva Supreme Virtuous King of Universal Illumination addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!

The Å›rÄvaka disciples are also like this. Because they do not see me, they think the TathÄgata has already entered parinirvÄá¹‡a between the twin Å›Äla trees in the city of KuÅ›inagara. But I am actually not in parinirvÄá¹‡a. The Å›rÄvaka disciples think of nirvÄá¹‡a.

The Å›rÄvaka disciples are also like this. Like those born blind, not seeing the TathÄgata, they say the TathÄgata has entered nirvÄá¹‡a. The TathÄgata is actually not entering nirvÄá¹‡a. It is due to inverted thoughts that they give rise to such thoughts.

There is what is called nirvana, but not great nirvana.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas cultivating the great nirvÄá¹‡a eliminate five things, distance themselves from five things, accomplish six things, cultivate five things, guard one thing, be close to four things, believe and follow the one truth, have a well-liberated mind, and have well-liberated wisdom.

How do bodhisattvas eliminate five things?
Namely, the five aggregates: form, feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness.
What is the meaning of the term aggregate?

It causes sentient beings to continue in birth and death, not to be free from heavy burdens, to disperse and gather, and to be included in the three times. Seeking its meaning and principles, it cannot be found. For these reasons, it is called an aggregate.

Although feelings are one hundred and eight, in principle they are not definitely real. Therefore, the bodhisattva does not see the aggregate of feeling. The same is true for the aggregates of perception, mental formations, and consciousness.

First, the view of the self; second, the extreme view; third, wrong view; fourth, attachment to rules and rituals; fifth, attachment to views.
Because of these five views, sixty-two views arise, and because of these views, birth and death are not severed. Therefore, bodhisattvas guard against them and do not get close to them.

Bodhisattvas understand that all sentient beings return to the one path, and the one path refers to the Great Vehicle.
The buddhas and bodhisattvas, for the sake of sentient beings, divide it into three. Therefore, bodhisattvas believe and follow without going against it.

If it is originally unfettered, how can it be said that the mind is well liberated?

If it was originally without greed and only later has it, then the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas, who originally had no characteristics of greed, should all have it now.
World-Honored One!
It is like a barren woman who originally has no characteristics of giving birth. Even if one applies countless methods, a child cannot be obtained.
The mind is also like this. If it originally has no characteristics of greed, even if one creates various conditions, greed cannot arise.
World-Honored One!
It is like trying to get fire from wet wood. It cannot be obtained.
The mind is also like this. Even if one seeks by rubbing, greed cannot be obtained.

World-Honored One!

It cannot be obtained. The mind is also like this. Even if one presses it, greed cannot be obtained.
One should know that greed and the mind have two different principles. Even if they exist, how can greed defile the mind?
World-Honored One!
It is like a person trying to drive a peg into empty space - it will never stay.
Placing greed in the mind is also like this - with various causes and conditions, one cannot cause greed to bind the mind.
World-Honored One!
If the mind without greed is called liberation, why do Buddhas and Bodhisattvas not pull out thorns from empty space?
World-Honored One!
The mind of the past is not called liberation.
The mind of the future also has no liberation.
The mind of the present is not together with the Way.
In which world's mind is liberation attained?
World-Honored One!
Just as a past lamp cannot extinguish darkness, a future lamp also does not extinguish darkness, and a present lamp also does not extinguish darkness.
Why is this?
Because light and darkness do not occur together.
The mind is also like this - how can it be said that the mind attains liberation?
World-Honored One!
Greed also exists. If greed did not exist, one would not give rise to greed upon seeing a woman's form.
If it arises due to the woman's form, one should know that greed truly exists. Because of greed, one falls into the three evil destinies.
World-Honored One!
It is like a person who sees a painted woman and also gives rise to greed. Because of giving rise to greed, one obtains various offenses.
If greed did not originally exist, how could one see a painting and give rise to greed?
If the mind is without greed, how can the Thus-Come One say that the bodhisattva's mind attains liberation?
If the mind has greed, how can one see a form and then give rise to it, while not giving rise to it if one does not see the form?
I now clearly see that there are evil karmic retributions. One should know that there is greed. Hatred and delusion are also like this.
World-Honored One!

It is like sentient beings who have bodies but no self. Yet, ordinary beings mistakenly give rise to the thought of self. Although there is the thought of self, one does not fall into the three evil destinies.
How is it that those who are greedy, without the notion of a woman, give rise to the thought of a woman and fall into the three evil destinies?
World-Honored One!
It is like rubbing two pieces of wood to create fire, yet the nature of fire does not exist among the various conditions. For what causes and conditions can it be born?
World-Honored One!
Greed is also like this. Greed does not exist in form, smell, taste, touch, or dharmas. How can greed arise towards form, smell, taste, touch, and dharmas?
If greed does not exist in all conditions, how can sentient beings alone give rise to greed?
Why do Buddhas and Bodhisattvas not give rise to it?
World-Honored One!
The mind is also not fixed. If the mind were fixed, there would be no greed, anger, or delusion.
If it is not fixed, how can it be said that the mind attains liberation?
Greed is also not fixed. If it is not fixed, how can it give rise to the three evil destinies?
Greed and objects are both not fixed.
Why is this?

When both arise in relation to a single form, sometimes greed arises, sometimes anger arises, and sometimes delusion arises. Therefore, both the greedy one and the object are both indeterminate. If they are both indeterminate, why did the Thus-Come One say that when bodhisattvas cultivate the great nirvÄá¹‡a, their minds attain liberation?
At that time the World-Honored One told the Bodhisattva-MahÄsattva Supreme Virtuous King of Universal Radiance, Excellent, excellent!
Good man!
The mind is also not bound by the fetters of greed, nor is it unbound. It is neither liberation nor non-liberation, neither existent nor non-existent, neither present nor past nor future.
Why is this?
Good man!
Because all dharmas have no inherent nature.
Good man!
There are non-Buddhists who say thus:

'If a result arises from the combination of causes and conditions, but the nature of arising is originally non-existent in the conditions, then even if space does not arise, it should be able to produce results.
Because space does not arise, it is not a cause. Since the nature of the result is originally present in the conditions, therefore they can combine to produce the result.
Why is this so?
If Devadatta wants to build a wall, he collects mud and earth, not paint.ğŸ”½If he wants to create a painting, he collects paint, not grass or wood.
If he wants to make clothes, he collects thread, not mud or wood.
If he wants to build a house, he collects mud, not thread.

Since people collect these things, we know that each can produce its own result. Since they can produce their own results, we know that the nature of the result must be present in the cause beforehand. If the nature were not present, then one thing should be able to produce all things.
If something can be collected, made, or produced, we know that the result must be present beforehand.
If there were no effects, people would not grasp, create, or emerge.
Only empty space, which is ungraspable and uncreatable, can give rise to all myriad things.
Because there are causes, like how a jujube seed produces a jujube tree, milk has ghee, thread has cloth, and clay has pots.
Good man, all ordinary beings, blinded by ignorance, make definitive statements that form has the meaning of attachment and the mind has the nature of craving.
They also say:

'The mind of ordinary beings has the nature of craving and also the nature of liberation. When encountering conditions of craving, the mind gives rise to craving; if encountering liberation, the mind is liberated.'
Although they make these statements, this is not the meaning.
There are also ordinary beings who say:
'All causes are devoid of effects.
There are two kinds of causes:ğŸ”½one is subtle and the other is coarse.
The subtle is permanent, while the coarse is impermanent.'
From subtle causes, they transform into coarse causes, and from these coarse causes, they further produce results.
Because the coarse is impermanent, the results are also impermanent.
Good sons!
There are also ordinary beings who say:
'The mind also has no cause, and greed also has no cause. It arises due to the passage of time.'
Such people, because they are unable to understand the causes and conditions of the mind, revolve through the six destinies and fully experience birth and death.
Good sons!
It is like a dog on a leash tied to a post, circling the post all day long, unable to escape.
All ordinary beings are also like this. Bound by the shackles of ignorance to the post of birth and death, they circle the twenty-five realms of existence, unable to escape.
Good sons!ğŸ”½It is like a person who falls into a cesspool, and after getting out, returns to enter it again.
It is like a person who recovers from an illness, but then becomes the cause of the illness again.
It is like a person traveling on a road who, having passed through an empty and desolate place, returns again.
It is also like washing something clean and then smearing it with mud and dirt.
All ordinary beings are also like this. They have already attained liberation in the sphere of nothingness.
They have only not yet attained liberation from the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception, and so they return again to the three evil destinies.
Why is this?
All ordinary beings only observe the effect and do not observe the causes and conditions, like a dog chasing after a clod of earth and not chasing after a person.

Ordinary beings are also like this. They only observe the effect and do not observe the causes and conditions. Because they do not observe, they fall from the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception and return to the three evil destinies.
Good man!

The buddhas and bodhisattvas never definitively say that there is an effect in the cause, that there is no effect in the cause, that there is both an effect and no effect, or that there is neither an effect nor no effect.

If one says that the effect is definitely existent, nonexistent, both existent and nonexistent, or neither existent nor nonexistent in the cause, one should know that such people are all the companions of Mara, bound to Mara, and are those who love;
such loving people cannot permanently sever the bonds of birth and death, and do not know the characteristics of the mind and greed.
Good man!
The buddhas and bodhisattvas reveal the middle way.
Why is it so?
Although it is said that all dharmas are neither existent nor nonexistent, it is not definite.
Why is it so?

Because of the eye, because of form, because of light, because of mind, because of recollection, consciousness can arise. This consciousness is definitely not in the eye, in the form, in the light, in the mind, in the recollection, nor in between, nor existent, nor nonexistent. Because it arises from conditions, it is called existent. Because it has no intrinsic nature, it is called nonexistent. Therefore, the Buddha says that all dharmas are neither existent nor nonexistent.
Good man!
The buddhas and bodhisattvas never definitively say that the mind has a nature of purity or impurity, or a nature of both purity and impurity, because the mind has no fixed abode.
Because it gives rise to craving through conditions, it is said not to be nonexistent. Because it is originally devoid of the nature of craving, it is said not to exist.
Good man!
The mind gives rise to craving because of conditions, and because of conditions it is liberated.
Good man!
There are two kinds of conditions:
One is following birth and death, the other is following great nirvana.
Good man!

Because of conditions, the mind gives rise to craving and perishes together with craving. There is that which gives rise to craving but does not perish with craving. There is that which does not give rise to craving but perishes together with craving. There is that which does not give rise to craving and does not perish with craving.
What is meant by the mind giving rise to craving and perishing together with craving?
Good man!
